summary: This video provides an explanation of litmus as an indicator used to identify acids and bases through various demonstrations and verbal explanations.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up shot of a clear glass beaker placed on a dark surface, containing a small amount of clear liquid. A dropper filled with red liquid is then introduced, and the red liquid is carefully added to the beaker, causing the clear liquid to turn blue. The camera zooms in to show the blue liquid more clearly, with the dropper still visible. The scene then transitions to a black screen with the word "Litmus:" written in white, accompanied by a hand icon, indicating the use of litmus paper or solution in the experiment. The video concludes with this text and icon on the black background, suggesting an educational or instructional context related to chemistry or science experiments.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a color-changing experiment. He explains that a "red color solution" turns blue when mixed with a liquid, clarifying that it is a "chemical reaction," and that "this red color solution is a litmus." He plans to talk more about litmus. He defines litmus as "a dye" and "a colored substance."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black screen displaying the text "Litmus: dye" in white handwriting, accompanied by a hand cursor pointing at the word "dye." The scene transitions to a split-screen image featuring a bowl of curry with rice and vegetables on the left and a person with blue hair styled in a bun on the right, both under the same "Litmus: dye" text. A third image of various colored fabrics hanging on a rack appears on the right side of the screen, maintaining the "Litmus: dye" text. The video then shifts to a close-up of green lichens on a branch, with the text "Litmus: dye Lichens" displayed at the top. The hand cursor points at the word "Lichens," emphasizing the connection between lichens and dye. The video concludes with a static image of the lichens, reinforcing the educational theme of natural dyes derived from lichens.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a single male voice describing the use of dyes to color various things, explaining litmus dye is derived from lichens, which are a combination of algae and fungus, and the litmus changes color when in contact with an acid or base. The voice is informative and clear. The speaker describes the litmus helping to identify acidic and basic solutions. The voice then concludes by saying, "Now, you might be wondering"

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up shot of a branch covered in green lichen, accompanied by the text "Litmus: dye Lichens" at the top, indicating the use of lichens as natural dyes. The scene transitions to a split-screen image of lemons and oranges, with the text "Acids taste Sour" above, highlighting the sour taste of acidic fruits. Following this, the video shows a split-screen of bitter vegetables, including bitter gourds and spinach, with the text "Bases taste bitter" above, emphasizing the bitter taste of basic foods. The video then shifts to a black screen with the word "Indicators" written in white, followed by a hand icon pointing to the word "Colour" and then to "Smell," suggesting that indicators can be identified by their color and smell. The video concludes with a black screen displaying the word "Indicators" in white, with arrows pointing to "Colour" and "Smell," reinforcing the concept that indicators can be recognized by their color and smell.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker questioning the necessity of a topic. Another male speaker responds, speaking in a conversational and educational tone, explaining that acids taste sour, bases taste bitter, and how indicators are used as some acids and bases can be poisonous. He states that Litmus is a type of indicator and references discussing more indicators in a separate video.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black background featuring a white line and the word "Indicators" written in white cursive font at the top. Below the line, the word "Colours" is written in white, with an arrow pointing to the word "Litmus" written in orange. To the right of the line, the word "Smell" is written in white. The scene transitions to a split-screen view, with the left side showing a brown bottle labeled "DIAGNOSTIC REAGENTS FOR LABORATORY USE ONLY" with a blue liquid inside, and the right side showing a similar bottle with a red liquid. The text "Blue litmus solution" appears in blue on the left side, and "Red litmus solution" appears in red on the right side. The next scene shows a hand holding a dropper with blue liquid, labeled "Blue litmus solution," above a beaker containing a clear liquid. The hand then drops the blue liquid into the beaker, turning the liquid red. The text "Acid" appears in white on the right side of the screen, with "Blue -> Red" written below it in blue and red, respectively. The video continues with a split-screen view, showing the left side with the blue liquid turning red in the beaker, and the right side with a dropper containing red liquid above a beaker with clear liquid. The text "Base" appears in white on the right side, with "Red -> Blue" written below it in red and blue, respectively. The video demonstrates the color change of litmus solutions when exposed to acids and bases, with the blue litmus turning red in the presence of an acid and the red litmus turning blue in the presence of a base.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker introducing an experiment about how litmus changes color in the presence of acid and base. He elaborates that litmus solution typically comes in blue or red. He proceeds to describe adding a blue litmus solution to an acid and observing that the color slowly changes to red, thus indicating acids turn blue litmus red. Next, he talks about adding red litmus solution to a base and observing the color changing to blue, conveying that bases turn red litmus blue. The speaker then concludes that litmus helps identify whether a solution is an acid or a base.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a split-screen demonstration of acid and base reactions. On the left side, a beaker contains a red liquid with a blue dropper above it, labeled "Acid" with the text "Blue → Red" indicating the color change when acid is added. On the right side, another beaker holds a blue liquid with a red dropper above it, labeled "Base" with the text "Red → Blue" showing the color change when a base is added. The background is a simple, neutral-colored surface, and the focus is on the chemical reactions. As the video progresses, additional text appears on the right side, explaining the reactions: "B Bases 2 to B Blue" and "B Bases R Red B Blue," clarifying the color changes for bases. The video maintains a clear and educational presentation of acid-base reactions, emphasizing the visual changes in color.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features one male speaker explaining the behavior of acids and bases in relation to litmus paper, with a clear and educational tone. He emphasizes how litmus paper changes color in the presence of an acid or base, providing mnemonic devices to help with memorization. The speaker transitions to clarifying a specific point about acids turning blue litmus red, maintaining the instructional tone throughout.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a split-screen image showing two beakers, one labeled "Acid" and the other "Base," with text indicating the color change of the liquid when an acid or base is added. The "Acid" side shows a blue liquid turning red, while the "Base" side shows a red liquid turning blue. The scene transitions to a close-up of a beaker with a red liquid, where a dropper is used to add a blue liquid, causing the mixture to turn purple. The next scene shows two beakers, one with a dark purple liquid and the other with a red liquid. A hand holding a lemon squeezes its juice into the beaker with the red liquid, turning it a deeper red. The video concludes with the two beakers side by side, one with a dark purple liquid and the other with a red liquid, indicating the completion of the experiment.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker discussing the effects of red litmus paper on acids, posing a question about color changes. The tone is inquisitive and educational. He then encourages the listener to pause and think about the question before he provides an answer. Continuing his explanation, he describes how acids and bases interact with litmus paper. To further illustrate the point, he references an experiment with lemons and litmus, demonstrating the color change of blue litmus when lemon juice is added and noting the lack of change when red litmus is exposed to lemon juice. He concludes by summarizing the concept of litmus color changes in contact with acids or bases.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with two beakers filled with red liquid placed on a black surface. The beakers are positioned side by side, with the one on the left slightly smaller than the one on the right. The background is a plain, light-colored wall. The scene then transitions to show the same beakers, now filled with clear liquid, indicating that the red liquid has been removed or replaced. The beakers remain in the same position, and the background remains unchanged. The video concludes with the beakers still containing clear liquid, with no further changes or actions occurring.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing solutions that are "neither acidic nor basic," such as water, which he describes as a "neutral solution." He asks if the listener can guess the color change of litmus in contact with water, inviting them to pause the video to make a guess. He suggests that instead of telling the answer, he will show an experiment.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with two beakers filled with clear liquid placed on a black surface. A hand holding a dropper appears and adds a red liquid to the right beaker, turning it red. The hand then adds a blue liquid to the left beaker, turning it blue. The scene transitions to a black background with white text that reads "Acids" and "Bases," accompanied by a hand icon pointing to the text. The text changes to "Acids Blue -> Red" and "Bases Red -> Blue," with the hand icon pointing to the respective colors. The video concludes with the text "Acids Blue -> Red" and "Bases Red -> Blue" displayed on the black background, with the hand icon pointing to the colors.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a female speaker who says that she has two containers of water and is going to add litmus to each one of them. She adds red litmus to the first container and then states that the color remains red, and is not changing. She switches to blue litmus and adds it to the second container, noting that the color remains the same there as well. The speaker continues, explaining that litmus does not change color when it comes into contact with a neutral solution, with red litmus remaining red, and blue litmus remaining blue. The speaker then summarizes that acids turn blue litmus red, and red litmus will remain red in their presence. She then makes a conclusion of the opposite of this, that bases turn red litmus blue, and blue litmus will remain blue. There will be no color change noticeable there.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a blackboard with colorful chalk writing explaining the behavior of acids, bases, and neutral substances. Initially, the board displays the words "Acids" and "Bases" with arrows indicating color changes: "Blue -> Red" for acids and "Red -> Blue" for bases. A hand cursor points to the word "Neutral," which is then written on the board with the phrase "No Colour change" in yellow chalk. The board also shows two circles, one with "Red" crossed out and the other with "Blue" crossed out, indicating no color change for neutral substances. The hand cursor then points to the letters "B2B" and "B RB," which are written in blue and pink chalk, respectively. The video concludes with a question written in red chalk: "On adding blue litmus to a solution, no colour change is observed. What can this solution be?" with three options below: "a) Acid," "b) Base," and "c) Neutral," with the hand cursor pointing to the word "Neutral." The background remains consistently black throughout the video, emphasizing the colorful chalk writing.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker explaining that there will be no color change in a neutral solution, adding that a "blue litmus will remain blue and a red litmus will remain red." He explains a mnemonic used to remember this rule. He then asks a question, stating that, "on adding blue litmus to a solution no color change is observed," and asks, "What can the solution be?" He advises pausing the video and explains that the question is "slightly tricky." He says, "Okay, now if you've tried it, let's see".

events_list.video_caption: The video features a blackboard with colorful text explaining the properties of acids, bases, and neutral solutions. The text is written in various colors, with "Acids" in blue, "Bases" in red, and "Neutral" in white. The blackboard also includes diagrams and symbols, such as a red circle with "Red" and a blue circle with "Blue," representing the color changes in solutions when tested with indicators. The text "On adding blue Q:ltmus to a solution, no colour change is observed. What can this solution be?" is written in red, with options "Acid," "Base," and "Neutral" listed below. A hand cursor appears, pointing to the options, and then circles the word "Neutral," indicating the correct answer. The background remains consistent throughout the video, with the blackboard as the central focus. The video serves as an educational tool to teach about the chemical properties of different solutions.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker in an educational tone. He's explaining a scientific concept. He speaks about a "blue litmus" test, observing "no color change" and discusses the possibility of the solution being "neutral" or a "base". He suggests further testing with "red litmus solution" to determine this. There are no sounds of music or background noises.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a blackboard filled with colorful chalk writings explaining the properties of acids, bases, and neutral solutions, focusing on the behavior of blue litmus paper. It then transitions to a close-up of two hands holding litmus paper strips, one labeled "Litmus Red" and the other "Blue Litmus," against a neutral background. The video then returns to the blackboard, where additional information about litmus paper is written, including its ability to change color and its use as an indicator. The final frames show a hand pointing to the words "Litmus" and "Changes Colour," emphasizing the key concept of litmus paper's color-changing property in the presence of acids and bases. The video effectively combines visual demonstrations with educational content to explain the chemical properties of litmus paper.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker explaining that if a solution is neutral it will not change color, and if a solution changes from red to blue, it is a base. Then the male speaker mentions litmus paper. The speaker then explains that litmus paper is paper dipped in litmus solution, and litmus paper is handy and easy to carry. The speaker emphasizes that the chemical reactions are the same for both the solution and litmus paper. The speaker proceeds to describe the color changes of both red and blue litmus paper when exposed to a base or acid respectively. Finally, the same male speaker offers a summary of the video, including remembering the color changes of litmus paper in acid and base using the acronyms B to B or BRB, encouraging the listener to rewind and review any forgotten information.
